ALLEGATION:
It was alleged the agency failed to complete timely clearances and assessments
to add FP 1’s live-together-partner to an active license.
INVESTIGATION:
DCWL received this complaint on 3/31/21 from an anonymous source.
The following is a list of events in chronological order:
2

5/23/19 FP 1 informs agency that her boyfriend may be moving in.
5/24/19 Agency receives a clear criminal history of boyfriend
5/30/19 Boyfriend’s child abuse clearance comes back clear and he is added as a
substitute caregiver for FP 1
7/31/19 Boyfriend moves into the foster home
7/31/19 Ichat is rerun and comes back clear
8/06/19 Agency continues what they believe is the process of adding boyfriend to the
foster home license
10/9/19 Agency receives boyfriend’s child abuse clearance from the state of Ohio
1/15/20 Boyfriend gets fingerprinted
6/16/20 Agency requests and receives application with both signatures
6/18/20 Agency sends fingerprints and signed application to DCWL for processing
7/15/20 Agency requests boyfriend submit a mental health assessment
9/25/20 Mental Health assessment of boyfriend completed
10/28/20 Agency learns boyfriend’s fingerprints are positive for criminal hit(s) and an
ART is required.
11/7/20 FP 1 and boyfriend marry
03/29/21 Agency completes an ART on FP1’s husband and sends it to DCWL
FP 1 notified Wolverine that her boyfriend may move in. Wolverine ran criminal and
central registry clearances to add him as a household member before he moved in.
The clearances came back clear.
Based on current protocol, an ichat and central registry clearance is sufficient to
determine the suitability of a new household member. However, an additional level of
protection is needed for when adding one’s name to an existing license in a 2-caregiver
household. That requires a signed application and finger printing.
Once FP1’s boyfriend moved in, FP 1 identified him as a substitute caregiver.
Wolverine sent him to Orientation and Pride Training, a step that they believed
“continued the process” of adding him to the license. However, Wolverine did not begin
“the process” at that time because the first step in the process is to sign an application.
TA manual – pg 19 indicates:
“In a two-caregiver household, both caregivers must sign the application. This would
include a husband and wife; a married couple where both individuals are the same
gender; two adult living together partners, regardless of gender; or two other adults who
will share the caregiver role.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12308 Application submission.
(2) An agency shall require both caregivers in a 2-caregiver
household to sign the application.
ANALYSIS: Wolverine waited nearly one year after FP1’s boyfriend moved
in to submit an application signed by the boyfriend. As FP1’s
live-together partner, the boyfriend should have signed the
application immediately after moving in.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Technical Assistance –
I recommend the agency refer to the CPA TA manual to assist them and/or contact
their assigned DCWL Office Consultant whenever they have questions related to
two-caregiver households.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is submitted, I recommend the agency
continue their current licensing status.
